The Iran-Iraq Arms Non-Proliferation Act of 1992 is amended to clarify policy by replacing "chemical, biological, nuclear" with "weapons of mass destruction", expanding sanctions against Iran, and imposing sanctions on certain persons for acquiring weapons of mass destruction or related means. The Iran-Iraq Arms Non-Proliferation Act of 1992 is amended to include expeditious termination of contracts for goods or services, migration sanctions for individuals and corporations, and visa restrictions for entry into the United States. The Iran-Iraq Arms Non-Proliferation Act of 1992 is amended to include visa restrictions for entry into the United States for employees, agents, and financial institutions associated with sanctioned persons. Financial institutions are prohibited from providing loans or credit to sanctioned individuals, except for purchasing food or agricultural commodities. Sanctioned persons are also prohibited from transiting through United States territory. The Iran-Iraq Arms Non-Proliferation Act of 1992 now includes visa restrictions for entry into the US for employees, agents, and financial institutions linked to sanctioned individuals. Financial institutions are barred from offering loans or credit to sanctioned persons, except for buying food or agricultural commodities. Sanctioned individuals are also forbidden from transiting through US territory, with exceptions for emergencies related to aircraft or vessel safety. Exceptions to sanctions apply for defense articles or services under existing contracts or subcontracts. The Iran-Iraq Arms Non-Proliferation Act of 1992 includes visa restrictions for entry into the US for sanctioned individuals. Sanctions may be waived for defense articles or services deemed essential to national security. The Iran-Iraq Arms Non-Proliferation Act of 1992 imposes visa restrictions on sanctioned individuals entering the US. Additional mandatory sanctions against Iraq are to be applied to other sanctioned countries. Discretionary sanctions under the Act have been amended to ensure consistency in enforcement. The Iran-Iraq Arms Non-Proliferation Act of 1992 imposes visa restrictions on sanctioned individuals entering the US. Additional mandatory sanctions against Iraq are to be applied to other sanctioned countries. Discretionary sanctions under the Act have been amended to ensure consistency in enforcement, including the use of authorities of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act for sanctioned countries. Beginning on the 10th day after a sanction is imposed against a country, a vessel entering a sanctioned country may not load or unload freight in the US within 180 days of departure. The term 'vessel' includes water craft but not aircraft. The President may notify the government of the sanctioned country regarding aviation actions. The President may notify the government of a sanctioned country about suspending the authority of foreign air carriers owned or controlled by that country for engaging in air transportation to or from the United States. The President can direct the Secretary of Transportation to suspend the authority of any foreign air carrier owned or controlled by the sanctioned country, regardless of any existing agreements. Additionally, the President can instruct the Secretary of State to terminate any air service agreement between the United States and the sanctioned country. Upon termination of an agreement, the Secretary of Transportation will revoke the right of any foreign air carrier owned or controlled by a country to engage in air transportation to or from the United States. The President can provide exceptions for emergencies threatening aircraft safety. Terms like 'air carrier', 'air transportation', 'aircraft', and 'foreign air carrier' have specific meanings. The text discusses the sanctions imposed on governments assisting Iran in improving its rocket technology or weapons capability, in line with the Iraq Sanctions Act of 1990. Additionally, it mentions the termination of sanctions against certain persons under the Act. The text discusses amendments to section 1605 of the Iraq Sanctions Act of 1990, including changes to the duration of sanctions imposed by the United States. The text discusses amendments to section 1605 of the Iraq Sanctions Act of 1990, including changes to the duration of sanctions imposed by the United States. The amendments include removing specific time periods mentioned in paragraphs (4) and (5) and adding a new section after section 1606. The text discusses the termination of sanctions under section 1606A of the Iraq Sanctions Act of 1990. Sanctions will cease to apply to a sanctioned person or government 30 days after the President certifies to Congress that they have stopped violating the act. Additionally, a new section 1607A on rules and regulations is added to the Act. The President can establish rules and regulations to implement this title. Definitions in Section 1608 of the Act are amended to include naval vessels with offensive capabilities and to address threats to international shipping. The term "United States assistance" refers to aid under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The term 'goods or technology' includes items listed on specific lists related to nuclear proliferation or subject to licensing by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The term 'United States' encompasses territories, possessions, and customs waters. The term 'weapons of mass destruction' is defined. The term 'weapons of mass destruction' includes nuclear, chemical, and biological weapons. Amendments are made to sections 1606 and 1607 of the Act, changing the committees in the House of Representatives to National Security and International Relations. Amendments are made to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Iraq Sanctions Act of 1990 regarding weapons of mass destruction and advanced conventional weapons.
